questions.text: Identify the bone in given image forming a crucial part of the auditory ossicles chain for sound transmission?"
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

Option B:

 

  • The given bone in the image is the ear ossicle - Incus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MALLEUS: Head-articulates with body of incus to form saddle synovial joint. Handle -medial surface upper end receives tensor tympani insertion. Handle embedded in fibrous layer of tympanic membrane. Anterior process-anterior ligament of malleus, Lateral process- Anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

Option C. STAPES: Head articulate with incus to form ball and socket joint, Neck -insertion of stapedius and Anterior and posterior limbs connected by footplate of stapes-closes fenestra vestibule.

 

Option D. Vomer: It is unpaired bone, contributes to posteroinferior portion of nasal septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Body forms saddle synovial joint with incus, short process -ligament to fossa incudis and Long process-tip forms ball and socket synovial joint with head of stapes.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th edition pg 284

questions.text: Structure passing through probed opening:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary Nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • The pointed structure is foramen rotundum.

  • The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (V2) passes through the foramen rotundum. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the mid-face, including the upper jaw and maxillary sinuses.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3) passes through the foramen ovale. This nerve carries sensory and motor fibers to the face and jaw.

 

Option C: Several cranial nerves and blood vessels pass through the internal acoustic meatus:

 

  • Facial Nerve (VII): The facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus before exiting the skull.

  • Vestibulocochlear Nerve (VIII): This nerve is responsible for hearing and balance. It also passes through the internal acoustic meatus.

  • Internal Auditory Artery and Vein: These blood vessels accompany the cranial nerves through the internal acoustic meatus.

 

Option D: Abducens nerve enters orbit through intermediate compartment of superior orbital fissure. The superior orbital fissure is a complex opening in the skull that allows various structures to pass through, including Oculomotor Nerve (III), Trochlear Nerve (IV), Ophthalmic Division of the Trigeminal Nerve (V1), Abducens Nerve (VI) Superior Ophthalmic Vein and Branches of the ophthalmic artery and sympathetic nerves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Foramen rotundum which connects the middle cranial fossa with pterygopalatine fossa and traversed by maxillary nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 41

choices.text: Contains Third Part of Maxillary Artery
Medially communicates with Infratemporal Fossa
Communicates with Middle through Foramen Rotundum
Vidian Nerve Canal opens into it

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Pterygopalatine Fossa:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medially communicates with Infratemporal Fossa.

 

Option B:

 

  • The pterygopalatine fossa is a deep, cone-shaped space located between the maxilla, the sphenoid bone, and the palatine bone.

 

Location: The pterygopalatine fossa is situated posterior to the maxilla, anterior to the pterygoid process of the sphenoid bone, and superior to the palatine bone.

 

Boundaries:

 

  • Anterior: The posterior wall of the maxillary sinus.
  • Posterior: The root of the pterygoid process of the sphenoid bone.
  • Medial: The perpendicular plate of the palatine bone.
  • Lateral: The pterygomaxillary fissure, which connects the fossa to the infratemporal fossa.
  • Superior: The body of the sphenoid bone.
  • Inferior: The palatine bone, specifically the horizontal plate, leading into the oral cavity.

 

Contents:

 

The pterygopalatine fossa contains several important structures:

 

  • The maxillary nerve (V2), the second branch of the trigeminal nerve, which enters the fossa through the foramen rotundum.
  • The pterygopalatine ganglion, which hangs from the maxillary nerve and is associated with the facial nerve (CN VII) for parasympathetic innervation.
  • Branches of the maxillary artery, which is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Veins that correspond to the branches of the maxillary artery, forming the pterygoid plexus.

 

Connections: The pterygopalatine fossa connects to other regions through several openings, allowing the passage of nerves and vessels:

 

  • Inferiorly: To the oral cavity via the greater and lesser palatine canals.
  • Laterally: To the infratemporal fossa via the pterygomaxillary fissure.
  • Medially: To the nasal cavity via the sphenopalatine foramen.
  • Superiorly: To the orbit via the inferior orbital fissure.
  • Posteriorly: To the middle cranial fossa via the foramen rotundum and to the pterygoid canal.

 

These connections make the pterygopalatine fossa a crucial crossroads for the distribution of nerves and vessels to the face, orbit, nasal cavity, and palate.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Maxillary artery divided by lateral pterygoid muscle into 3 parts. The first and second part lie in infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Maxillary division of trigeminal nerve reaches pterygopalatine fossa via foramen rotundum.

 

Option D: Nerve of pterygoid canal reaches pterygopalatine fossa from middle cranial fossa via vidain nerve canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygopalatine fossa medially related to perpendicular plate of palatine bone and laterally communicates with infratemporal fossa.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 110

questions.text: Identify the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gasserian Ganglion

 

Option D: The pointed structure is the trigeminal ganglion in fossa of dura mater called Gasserian ganglion.

 

Gasserian ganglion: It contains pseudounipolar neurons.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Langley’s ganglia is the other name for submandibular ganglia. Langley's ganglion isn't a widely recognized term in standard anatomical nomenclature. It could potentially be a less common name for a specific ganglion, possibly related to the work of John Newport Langley, an English physiologist who made significant contributions to the understanding of the autonomic nervous system.

 

Option B: Meckel’s ganglia is the other name for pterygopalatine ganglion, is located in the pterygopalatine fossa, near the maxillary nerve. It is a parasympathetic ganglion that plays a crucial role in innervating the lacrimal glands (contributing to tear production) and various glands in the nasal cavity and palate. It involves functions such as nasal secretion and dilation of blood vessels in the nasal cavity.

 

Option C: Geniculate ganglion is located at the external genu of facial nerve. The geniculate ganglion is a sensory ganglion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) located in the facial canal. It contains the cell bodies of sensory neurons that bring taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and cutaneous sensations from the external ear. It is also involved in the sensory pathway for the facial nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gasserian ganglion, more commonly known as the trigeminal ganglion, is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), the largest of the cranial nerves. It is located in a cavity called Meckel's cave, part of the temporal bone. This ganglion contains the cell bodies of sensory neurons that carry information from the face, including touch, pain, and temperature sensations. The trigeminal nerve has three major branches: the ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves, which innervate different regions of the face.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg380

questions.text: A 28-year-old male sustained head injury due to fall from his bike. CT brain showed extradural hematoma. The blood vessel injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle Meningeal Artery

 

Option C:

 

  • Rupture of middle meningeal vessels results in extradural haemorrhage

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Middle Cerebral Artery is a major artery in the brain that supplies blood to lateral parts of the brain, including the lateral temporal and frontal lobes, and part of the parietal lobe. Injury to the Middle Cerebral Artery usually leads to an intracerebral hemorrhage or a subarachnoid hemorrhage, not an extradural hematoma. This artery is located deep within the brain tissue and is not typically involved in extradural bleedings.

 

Option B. Superior cerebral veins drain the cerebral hemispheres and empty into the superior sagittal sinus. While venous bleeding can occur due to head trauma, it is more likely to result in a subdural hematoma rather than an extradural one. The venous bleeding is usually slower than arterial bleeding and often occurs over a larger surface area.

 

Option D. The Accessory Meningeal Artery is a smaller artery that also supplies the meninges. While it could potentially be involved in an extradural bleed, it is much less likely than the Middle Meningeal Artery, given its smaller size and different anatomical course.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anatomy: The Middle Meningeal Artery is a branch of the maxillary artery and runs between the skull and the dura mater.
  • Relation to Extradural Hematoma: This artery is the most commonly injured vessel in extradural hematomas, particularly when there is a fracture of the temporal bone, as it runs within the grooves on the inner surface of the skull.
  • Trauma can lead to its rupture, causing rapid bleeding and the formation of an extradural hematoma.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 313

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a persistent, dull pain in his left ear and a recent onset of a metallic taste in his mouth. He has a history of chronic ear infections but denies any recent infections or trauma. Otoscopic examination reveals no acute inflammation or infection in the external auditory canal or tympanic membrane. Given the patient's symptoms and history, which anatomical structure in the middle ear, if affected, could explain his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Floor

 

Option B:

 

  • Tympanic branch of IX nerve is called Jacobson's nerve, it enters middle ear by piercing the floor -jugular fossa which lodges superior bulb of IJV

 

 

  • Jacobson's nerve, also known as the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), enters the middle ear cavity through a small canal in the floor of the middle ear, known as the tympanic canaliculus.
  • This nerve provides innervation to the mucosa of the middle ear and the mastoid air cells and participates in the formation of the tympanic plexus.
  • It also carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, which can explain the metallic taste in the patient's mouth if the nerve is irritated or damaged.
  • The persistent dull ear pain without signs of acute infection could be related to chronic changes or irritation in the middle ear affecting Jacobson's nerve.
  • The other options (roof, anterior wall, and posterior wall) are not typical entry points for Jacobson's nerve into the middle ear and would not directly explain the combination of ear pain and altered taste sensation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Roof is formed by tegmen tympani and pierced by greater and lesser petrosal nerve.

 

Option C: Anterior wall -lower part -carotid canal and pierced by superior and inferior caroticotympanic nerves.

 

Option D: Posterior wall is related to the vertical course of facial nerve in its bony canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Jacobson's nerve, also known as the tympanic nerve, is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). It carries parasympathetic fibers to the middle ear and is involved in the innervation of the mucosa of the middle ear, the mastoid air cells, and the Eustachian tube.
  • Jacobson's nerve enters the middle ear by piercing the floor of the tympanic cavity. It does so through a small canal known as the tympanic canaliculus, which is located near the promontory of the medial wall of the middle ear.
  • After entering the middle ear, the tympanic nerve contributes to the formation of the tympanic plexus on the surface of the promontory.
  • This plexus is involved in providing sensory innervation to the mucous membrane of the tympanic cavity and mastoid air cells, as well as contributing parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion via the lesser petrosal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 278

choices.text: The Optic Nerves are surrounded by Sheaths derived from the Pia Mater, Arachnoid Mater, and Dura Mater
The Intracranial Subarachnoid space extends forward around the Optic Nerve as far as the back of the Eyeball.
The Ciliary Ganglion is situated between the proximal part of Medial Rectus and Optic Nerve
The Nerve to Medial Rectus is seen Inferior to the Optic Nerve

questions.text: A 75-year-old man was found on ophthalmoscopic examination to have edema of both optic discs (bilateral papilledema) and congestion of both retinal veins. The cause of the condition was found to be a rapidly expanding intracranial tumor. Which of the following statements is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Ciliary Ganglion is situated between the proximal part of Medial Rectus and Optic Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • The ciliary ganglion is situated between the proximal part of the lateral rectus and optic nerve close to the apex of the orbit.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The optic nerve is indeed surrounded by extensions of the three meningeal layers (pia, arachnoid, and dura), which provide it with a protective sheath.

 

Option B. The subarachnoid space extends along the optic nerve up to the back of the eye. This anatomical feature is significant in the context of papilledema, where increased intracranial pressure can lead to optic disc swelling observable in an ophthalmoscopic examination.

 

Option D. The nerve to the medial rectus, a branch of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), is indeed located inferior to the optic nerve as it enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ciliary ganglion is actually located in the posterior orbit in the lateral part of the optic nerve, not between the optic nerve and the medial rectus muscle.
  • The ganglion is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the eye, particularly controlling the pupillary sphincter and ciliary muscles.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition pg no666

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss

questions.text: A four-year-old girl was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat and runny nose for the past two weeks. Her mother reported that she also complained of pain in the left ear at night. On examination of the oral cavity the tonsils were found to be enlarged. Examination of her ears with the otoscope showed both eardrums were congested and looked reddish especially on the left. She was prescribed with decongestant medication and analgesics and requested to come for a review a week later. If this patient was left untreated all of the following possible complications will occur, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialolithiasis 

 

Option D:

  • Sialolithiasis refers to the formation of salivary gland stones (sialoliths). It is unrelated to ear infections or their complications. Salivary gland stones can cause pain and swelling in the affected salivary gland (typically the submandibular gland) and can lead to infection if left untreated.

 

Explanation:

Option A. Conductive Hearing loss. This can occur due to the effusion and congestion of the middle ear associated with otitis media, which can impede sound transmission.

 

Option B. Mastoiditis is a potential complication of untreated or inadequately treated acute otitis media. It occurs when the infection spreads to the mastoid bone located behind the ear. Mastoiditis can lead to severe pain, swelling, and potentially serious complications, including the spread of infection to nearby structures.

 

Option C. Meningitis is a rare but serious complication of untreated middle ear infections when the infection spreads from the ear to the lining of the brain and spinal cord. It can lead to life-threatening symptoms, including high fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When evaluating a case of otitis media and tonsillitis, it is important to recognize potential complications associated with the untreated condition, such as conductive hearing loss, mastoiditis, and, in severe cases, meningitis.

  • Sialolithiasis, the formation of salivary stones, is not associated with these conditions.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 275

choices.text: It arises from the lesser wing of sphenoid
It is inserted into the eyeball behind the equator
It is supplied by trochlear nerve
It causes extorsion of eyeball

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about the pointed structure in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It causes extorsion of eyeball

 

Option D:

 

The pointed structure is the superior oblique muscle of the eyeball.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The pointed structure is superior oblique muscle of eyeball. It arises from the undersurface of lesser wing of sphenoid above and medial to the common tendinous ring.

 

Option B. It is inserted into the posterosuperior quadrant of the eyeball behind the equator.

 

Option C. All extraocular muscles of eyeball are supplied by oculomotor nerve except lateral rectus (abducens nerve) & superior oblique (trochlear nerve).

 

Educational objective:

 

Superior oblique causes, abduction, depression and intorsion of eyeball.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 256

choices.text: 2, 3, 7

questions.text:
Branches from Second Part of Maxillary Artery are:

 

  1. Middle Meningeal Artery
  2. Masseteric Artery
  3. Sphenopalatine Artery
  4. Buccal Artery
  5. Accessory Meningeal Artery
  6. Anterior Tympanic Artery
  7. Deep Temporal Artery
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4, 7

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Maxillary artery is the larger terminal branch of the external carotid artery. It is divided into three parts by lateral pterygoid muscle.

 

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th edition pg 328-331

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the otolaryngologist with complaints of an earache, fever and some degree of hearing loss for the past three days. He had similar episodes in the past. On examination of the patient with an otoscope, an inflamed tympanic membrane that was bulging and opacified was noted. Pneumatic otoscopy confirmed the presence of fluid in the middle ear. The patient is diagnosed with acute otitis media. It was decided to perform a myringotomy in this patient. Where will the incision be placed in the tympanic membraneduring this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterioinferior portion

 

Option D:

 

  • An incision in the posteroinferior quadrant will avoid injury to chorda tympani and ossicles.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterosuperior part: Myringotomy is a procedure where an incision is made in the tympanic membrane to let out the fluid collection.  Deep to anterosuperior quadrant of tympanic membrane lies the tympanic opening of auditory tube. This area is typically not chosen for a myringotomy because it may not provide effective drainage of fluid from the middle ear.

 

Option B. Anteroinferior part: This area is also not commonly chosen for myringotomy as it may not allow for optimal drainage. Deep to anteroInferior portion of tympanic membrane lies the carotid canal

 

Option C. Posterosuperior portion: This area is less commonly chosen for myringotomy because it may not provide the best access for drainage. Deep to posterosuperior quadrant of tympanic membrane lies the long process of incus, stapes, fenestra vestibuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterioinferior portion: This area is the most commonly chosen location for myringotomy. It allows for effective drainage of fluid or pus from the middle ear, relieving pressure and pain associated with conditions like acute otitis media.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 273

choices.text: Anteroinferior angle of parietal bone is called Asterion
The enlarging blood clot exerts local pressure on the underlying Paracentral lobule
CT scan showed a long crescentic hematoma underneath the Temporal & Parietal bone
The burr hole through the Skull wall should be placed about 1.5 in (4 cm) above the midpoint of the Zygomatic Arch

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman had been hit on the side of the head by a bus while she tried to cross the highway. She was unconscious when admitted to the emergency department. Within an hour, she was found to have a large, dough-like swelling over the left temporal region. She also had signs of muscular paralysis on the right side of the body. A lateral radiograph of the skull showed a fracture line running downward and forward across the anterior—inferior angle of the left parietal bone. CT scan showed features suggestive of extradural haemorrhage. Craniotomy was planned. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The burr hole through the skull wall should be placed about 1.5 in (4 cm) above the midpoint of the zygomatic arch

 

Option D:

 

  • The pterion is located about 1.5 in (4 cm) above the midpoint of the zygomatic arch.
  • In extradural haemorrhage the middle meningeal artery, its anterior branch that lies underneath the anteroinferior angle of parietal bone is torn

 

Parietal bone:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The asterion is the anatomical landmark located where the occipital bone, parietal bone, and mastoid portion of the temporal bone meet. It is not the anteroinferior angle of the parietal bone. The anteroinferior angle of the parietal bone is at the front and bottom edge of the parietal bone, not at the junction described for the asterion.

 

Option B. While an enlarging hematoma can indeed exert pressure on underlying brain structures, the paracentral lobule is not typically affected in extradural hemorrhages associated with fractures of the temporal bone. Extradural hemorrhages often impact areas closer to the site of the fracture, such as the temporal lobe or underlying meningeal arteries, rather than the paracentral lobule, which is located more centrally on the medial surface of the brain.

 

Option C. Extradural hematomas are often crescent-shaped and can occur under the temporal and parietal bones, as they often result from arterial bleeding, typically from the middle meningeal artery, in the case of temporal bone fractures. However, without more information from the CT scan, it's challenging to confirm the full extent and exact location of the hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This is a standard approach for a burr hole in cases of extradural hematoma, especially when the hematoma is located in the temporal region.
     
  • The location described is typically used to access the temporal fossa, where extradural hematomas commonly accumulate.
  • The placement allows for safe and effective drainage of the hematoma while avoiding damage to the underlying brain tissue.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 14

questions.text: The nerve supply to the muscle which inserts into the pointed area in the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mandibular Nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • The pointed structure is upper part of handle of malleus which receives insertion of tensor tympani muscle.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Facial nerve innervates stapedius, muscle of middle ear.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve innervates stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Option D. Vagus nerve is motor to muscles of soft palate, pharynx and larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Upper part of handle of malleus which receives insertion of tensor tympani muscle which is innervated by branch from trunk of mandibular division of trigeminal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg No. 284

choices.text: Hypotympanum medially opens into the Eustachian tube
Mesotympanum is the narrowest part
Epitympanum communicates with the Mastoid Antrum through Aditus
Hypotympanum is the smallest part

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypotympanum medially opens into the Eustachian tube

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mesotympanum is indeed the narrowest part of the middle ear cavity. It is the central portion of the tympanic cavity, located between the hypotympanum and the epitympanum.

 

Option C. The epitympanum communicates with the mastoid antrum through a passage called the aditus. The mastoid antrum is a cavity within the mastoid process of the temporal bone, and the epitympanum is the upper portion of the middle ear cavity located above the level of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. The hypotympanum is generally considered the smallest part of the middle ear cavity. It is located inferiorly and posteriorly to the level of the tympanic membrane and is bounded by the tympanic membrane, the jugular fossa, and the bony floor of the middle ear

 

Educational objective:

 

Hypotympanum does not directly open into the Eustachian tube. The Eustachian tube connects the middle ear cavity to the nasopharynx. The hypotympanum is the lowest portion of the tympanic cavity and is located inferiorly to the level of the tympanic membrane. It does not directly open into the Eustachian tube. The Eustachian tube is connected to the anterior wall of the middle ear, not the hypotympanum. 

 

Note - Size of Epitympanum is 6mm, Mesotympanum is 2mm & Hypotympanum is 4mm.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 276

choices.text: Anterior tympanic artery is a branch from deep auricular artery
Superior tympanic artery is a branch from middle meningeal artery
Inferior tympanic artery is a branch from ascending pharyngeal artery
Posterior tympanic artery is from stylomastoid artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about the blood vessels shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior tympanic artery is a branch from deep auricular artery

 

Option A:

 

  • The anterior tympanic artery typically arises from the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery. Its primary role is to supply blood to the tympanic membrane (eardrum) and the adjacent parts of the middle ear. The deep auricular artery, also a branch of the maxillary artery, supplies the external acoustic meatus and outer ear but not typically the tympanic membrane.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The superior tympanic artery usually branches off from the middle meningeal artery, which itself is a branch of the maxillary artery. The superior tympanic artery supplies parts of the middle ear, including the tympanic membrane and the ossicles.

 

Option C. The inferior tympanic artery commonly arises from the ascending pharyngeal artery, a branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to the blood supply of the lower part of the tympanic cavity and the tympanic plexus.

 

Option D. The stylomastoid artery, which is a branch of the posterior auricular artery (itself a branch of the external carotid artery), primarily supplies the facial nerve and the mastoid cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  The anterior tympanic artery typically arises from the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery. Its primary role is to supply blood to the tympanic membrane (eardrum) and the adjacent parts of the middle ear. The deep auricular artery, also a branch of the maxillary artery, supplies the external acoustic meatus and outer ear but not typically the tympanic membrane.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 276

questions.text: Which of the following nerves transmits from the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zygomatic Nerve

 

Option B: The pointed structure is the inferior orbital fissure.

 

The zygomatic nerve is a branch of the maxillary nerve. After the maxillary nerve enters the orbit through the inferior orbital fissure, it gives off the zygomatic nerve. The zygomatic nerve carries sensory fibers from the cheek and temporal region.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Maxillary Nerve, which is the second branch of the trigeminal nerve, indeed passes through the inferior orbital fissure. It enters the pterygopalatine fossa after passing through the fissure and then continues into the orbit through the infraorbital groove and canal to become the infraorbital nerve.

 

Option C: The frontal nerve does not pass through the inferior orbital fissure. It is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, the first division of the trigeminal nerve. The frontal nerve enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure, not the inferior one, and divides into the supraorbital and supratrochlear nerves.

 

Option D: Nasociliary Nerve, another branch of the ophthalmic nerve, also does not pass through the inferior orbital fissure. Like the frontal nerve, it enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure. The nasociliary nerve provides sensory innervation to the eyeball, eyelids, and nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inferior orbital fissure transmits infraorbital vessels and nerve, zygomatic nerve, orbital branch from pterygopalatine ganglion, communications between inferior ophthalmic veins and pterygoid venous plexus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 252

choices.text: Greater Petrosal Nerve
Deep Petrosal Nerve
Lesser Petrosal Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the pointed Foramen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lesser Petrosal Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • The pointed opening is foramen ovale. Lesser petrosal nerve arises from the tympanic plexus of middle ear contributed by Jacobson’s nerve and passes through foramen ovale.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Greater petrosal nerve is a branch from geniculate ganglion. The greater petrosal nerve is a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and carries parasympathetic and sensory fibers. It arises from the geniculate ganglion and passes through the middle cranial fossa. The nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal gland (involved in tear production) and to mucous membranes of the nose and palate. It travels through the foramen lacerum (though not passing entirely through it, as this foramen is mostly filled with cartilage) and enters the pterygoid canal, where it combines with the deep petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve).

 

Option B: Deep petrosal nerve arises from plexus around internal carotid artery. The deep petrosal nerve carries postganglionic sympathetic fibers from the carotid plexus. It does not contain sensory or parasympathetic fibers. The deep petrosal nerve passes through the carotid canal alongside the internal carotid artery and then through the foramen lacerum, though it does not exit the skull through this foramen. It joins with the greater petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid canal, which then passes through the pterygoid canal to reach the pterygopalatine ganglion.

 

Option D: Jacobson’s nerve is tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve. It enters the middle ear cavity through a small canal called the tympanic canaliculus, which is located near the jugular fossa. The nerve contributes to the formation of the tympanic plexus on the promontory of the middle ear. The tympanic plexus gives rise to the lesser petrosal nerve. Jacobson's nerve is involved in providing sensory innervation to the mucosa of the middle ear, the mastoid antrum, and the auditory tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Foramen Ovale: Structures traversing -mandibular nerve, accessory meningeal artery, lesser petrosal nerve, emissary vein.
  • The lesser petrosal nerve is a parasympathetic nerve that originates from the tympanic plexus, which is formed by the tympanic nerve (a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, cranial nerve IX) and branches from the carotid plexus. The lesser petrosal nerve exits the skull through the foramen ovale (or sometimes through a small canal adjacent to it) and carries parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion, after which postganglionic fibers innervate the parotid gland to stimulate saliva production.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 40

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of a persistent dull throat pain that radiates to his left ear. He mentions that the pain worsens when he turns his head or swallows. The patient also reports a sensation of a foreign body in his throat. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he denies any recent trauma or infection. On physical examination, palpation of the tonsillar fossa elicits the pain and reproduces the sensation he has been complaining about. On examination pointed structure was involved. Name the syndrome related to the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eagle Syndrome

 

Option B:

 

  • The pointed structure is a styloid process of temporal bone.
  • Eagle's Syndrome is characterized by a variety of symptoms, including throat pain, sensation of a foreign body in the throat, pain radiating to the ear, and discomfort during head movement or swallowing.
  • These symptoms are due to an elongated styloid process or calcification of the stylohyoid ligament.
  • The diagnosis is often clinical, supported by radiographic evidence of an elongated styloid process. The pain upon palpation of the tonsillar fossa, which reproduces the patient's symptoms, is a classic sign of Eagle's syndrome.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gradenigo`s Triad is characterized by 5th Cranial Nerve Involvement (Retro-orbital Pain, Paraesthesia over Face), 6th Cranial Nerve Involvement (Diplopia) and Persistent Ear Discharge 

 

Option C: Vernet syndrome refers to paralysis of IX, X, XI cranial nerves traversing through posterior compartment of jugular foramen.

 

Option D: Villaret syndrome involves IX, X, XI, XII and cervical sympathetic fibres. It is also called retropharyngeal space syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Styloid process of temporal bone: An abnormally elongated styloid process can damage the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is closely related to it producing otalgia, odynophagia, facial pain when turning the head.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 27

questions.text: Facial Nerve enters through which compartment of Internal Acoustic Meatus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anterosuperior

 

Option D: Facial nerve enters through the anterosuperior quadrant of the internal acoustic meatus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The anteroinferior quadrant presents tractus spiralis foraminous for transmission of cochlear nerve fibres.

 

Option B: Posteroinferior quadrant presents the inferior vestibular area for the inferior division of vestibular nerve. A foramen singular lies behind and below the inferior vestibular area for passage of a twig of vestibular nerve to reach the ampulla of the posterior semicircular duct.

 

Option C: Posterosuperior quadrant presents superior vestibular area for superior division of vestibular nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Structures traversing internal acoustic meats include – Facial nerve, Vestibulocochlear Nerve and Labyrinthine Artery. The facial nerve passes through the anterosuperior quadrant.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 293

choices.text: Passes Above the Vestibule of Inner Ear
Oblique Course over Medial Wall of Middle Ear
Vertical Course over Posterior Wall of Middle Ear
Horizontal Course over Anterior Wall of Middle Ear

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the Intrapetrous Course of Facial Nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Horizontal Course over Anterior Wall of Middle Ear

 

Option D:

 

  • Intrapetrous course of facial nerve doesn’t passes the horizontal course over anterior wall of middle ear.

 

 

 

  • Anterior wall of middle ear in lower part presents posterior wall of bony carotid canal and is perforated by superior and inferior caroticotympanic nerves.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: At the bottom of internal acoustic meatus the two roots of facial nerve unite to form a trunk which enters the bony facial canal and passes laterally above the vestibule of inner ear.

 

Option B: Facial nerve reaches the medial wall of epitympanic part of middle ear where it forms the external genu and presents geniculate ganglion.

 

 

Option C: From the genu facial nerve passes backward and downward lodging in the bony canal above the promontory and fenestra vestibuli. Then it descends vertically along the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity and exits through stylomastoid foramen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

After entering the temporal bone through the internal acoustic meatus, the facial nerve (CN VII) traverses the petrous part of the temporal bone in a complex path divided into segments:

 

  1. Labyrinthine Segment: The shortest and narrowest part, which is located between the internal acoustic meatus and the geniculate ganglion.
  2. Tympanic Segment (Horizontal Segment): After the geniculate ganglion, the nerve turns sharply backward (at the first genu) to run horizontally in a bone canal called the facial canal. This segment is indeed above the oval window and crosses the medial (internal) wall of the tympanic cavity (middle ear) horizontally. It is at this point that the nerve is closest to the middle ear cavity, making it vulnerable during middle ear surgeries.
  3. Mastoid Segment (Vertical Segment): After the horizontal segment, the nerve makes a second sharp turn (at the second genu) to descend vertically in the posterior part of the temporal bone, heading toward the stylomastoid foramen, from where it exits the skull.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 395

choices.text: Superior Petrosal Sinus
Inferior Petrosal Sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of Trautmann's Triangle:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior Petrosal Sinus

 

Option B: Trautmann's triangle is a surgical landmark to reach the posterior cranial fossa from the mastoid. The inferior petrosal sinus doesn’t contribute to its boundary. Inferior petrosal sinus runs along inferior border of petrous bone.
 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The superior petrosal sinus is indeed one of the boundaries of Trautmann's triangle. It runs along the petrous ridge of the temporal bone and forms the anterior boundary of the triangle.

 

Option C: The sigmoid sinus is a key boundary of Trautmann's triangle, forming the posterior boundary. It is a continuation of the transverse sinus, curving downward to become the internal jugular vein, and its relationship to the triangle is crucial for surgical approaches to the cerebellopontine angle.

 

Option D: While the semicircular canals are located within the region of interest for surgeries involving Trautmann's triangle, they are not considered a boundary of the triangle itself. The semicircular canals are part of the inner ear and are important for balance and spatial orientation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trautmann's triangle, also known as the Cerebello Pontine Angle (CPA) cistern, is an anatomical region of significant clinical relevance, especially in neurosurgery and otolaryngology.
  • It's important for accessing lesions in the cerebellopontine angle, such as vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) and meningiomas. The boundaries of Trautmann's triangle help in understanding the surgical approach to this area.

 

The inferior petrosal sinus is not a boundary of Trautmann's triangle. It runs along the petroclival fissure, extending from the cavernous sinus to the jugular bulb, and is located more medially compared to the structures defining Trautmann's triangle.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 285

choices.text: Mastoid Antrum posteriorly related to Sigmoid Sinus
Lateral Wall is the usual Surgical approach to the Antrum
Anteroinferior Boundary of MacEwens Triangle corresponds with the Horizontal Part of Facial Nerve Canal
Mastoid Antrum achieves Full Adult Size at Birth

questions.text: A 30-year-old male visited the ENT OPD with complaints of fever, headache, ear pain and reduced hearing in the right ear. The patient also complained of pain in the right ear while eating. On examination, there was a small swelling behind the ear and severe tenderness over and behind the right ear. There was also a purulent discharge from the right ear. CT scan showed fluid in mastoid air cells and other features diagnostic of Mastoiditis with chronic suppurative otitis media. The patient was posted for cortical mastoidectomy. Which of the following statements is not true pertaining to the above case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anteroinferior Boundary of MacEwen’s Triangle corresponds with the Horizontal Part of Facial Nerve Canal

 

Option C:

 

  • In the described case of Mastoiditis with chronic suppurative otitis media, where cortical mastoidectomy is indicated, understanding the anatomy of the mastoid area is crucial.
  • MacEwens triangle is seen on the lateral wall of the antrum - point of surgical approach in cortical mastoidectomy.

 

Boundaries:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The mastoid antrum is indeed located posteriorly to the sigmoid sinus. The sigmoid sinus is a crucial landmark in mastoid surgery, and its relationship to the mastoid antrum is important to avoid injury during surgical procedures.

 

Option B: The lateral wall (cortical bone) of the mastoid process is typically approached in mastoid surgery, such as in a cortical mastoidectomy. This approach allows access to the mastoid air cells and the mastoid antrum while minimizing the risk to vital structures.

 

Option D: The mastoid antrum is one of the few parts of the mastoid process that is fully developed at birth. The rest of the mastoid air cells develop and pneumatize after birth, particularly in the first few years of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MacEwen's (or suprameatal) triangle is an important surgical landmark in mastoid surgery.
  • The anteroinferior boundary of this triangle corresponds to the spine of Henle, not the horizontal part of the facial nerve canal.
  • The facial nerve canal runs a course that is more medial, and inferior compared to this triangle. Misidentifying this relationship can lead to the risk of damaging the facial nerve during surgery.

 

Mastoid Antrum Boundaries:

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 624
